pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:0.5: 33. The training rule on eating a meal before another
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Vesālī in the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.2: At that time in Vesālī people had arranged a succession of fine meals.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.3: And a certain poor worker thought, “Why don’t I prepare a meal? It must be an important matter, in that these people prepare a meal with such respect.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.4: He then went to his boss Kira and said, “Sir, I wish to prepare a meal for the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.6: Because Kira also had faith and confidence,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.7: he gave the worker his salary and much extra.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.8: Soon afterwards that worker went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.9: “Venerable Sir, please accept a meal from me tomorrow together with the Sangha of monks.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.10: “Are you aware that the Sangha is large?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.12: I’ve prepared much jujube and also drinks mixed with jujube.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.13: The Buddha consented by remaining silent, and the worker understood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.14: The worker got up from his seat, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.15: The monks heard that a poor worker had invited the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha for a meal on the following day, complete with drinks mixed with jujube.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.16: And so they ate in the morning after walking for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.17: When people heard that a poor worker had invited the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha for a meal, they brought much food of various kinds to him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.18: The following morning that worker prepared his food, and then had the Buddha informed “It’s time, Sir, the meal is ready.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.19: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe and, together with the Sangha of monks, went to the house of that poor worker, where he sat down on the prepared seat in the dining hall.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.20: The worker served the monks, but they kept saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.22: “Venerables, don’t accept so little because you think I’m just a poor worker.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.23: I’ve prepared much food of various kinds.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.24: Please accept as much as you like.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.25: “We’re not accepting so little because of that,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.26: but because we ate in the morning after walking for alms.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.27: That poor worker complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.28: “How can the venerables eat elsewhere when invited by me?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.29: Am I not able to give as much as they need?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.30: The monks heard the complaints of that worker,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.31: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.32: “How can those monks eat elsewhere when invited for a meal?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.33: “Is it true, monks, that monks did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.36: “… How can those foolish men eat elsewhere when invited for a meal?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.37: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.38: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.39.1: ‘If a monk eats a meal before another, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:1.40: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:2.1: Soon afterwards a certain monk became sick.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:2.2: Another monk took some almsfood, went to that monk, and told him to eat it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:2.4: But that almsfood only arrived after midday, and that monk did not eat as much as he had intended.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:2.6: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:2.7: “Monks, I allow a sick monk to eat a meal before another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:2.8: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:2.9.1: ‘If a monk eats a meal before another, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:2.10: This is the appropriate occasion: he is sick.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:2.11: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.1: Soon afterwards, during the robe-giving season, people prepared a meal together with robe-cloth and then invited the monks, “We wish to offer you a meal and give you robe-cloth.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.2: Knowing that the Buddha had prohibited eating a meal before another and being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not accept.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.3: As a result they only obtained a small amount of robe-cloth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.5: “Monks, I allow you to eat a meal before another during the robe-giving season.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.6: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.7.1: ‘If a monk eats a meal before another, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.8: These are the appropriate occasions: he is sick; it is the robe-giving season.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.9: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.10.1: Soon afterwards people invited monks who were making robes for a meal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.11: Knowing that the Buddha had prohibited eating a meal before another and being afraid of wrongdoing, they did not accept.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.13: “Monks, I allow you to eat a meal before another at a time when you are making robes.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.14: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.15.1: ‘If a monk eats a meal before another, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.16: These are the appropriate occasions: he is sick; it is the robe-giving season; it is a time of making robes.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:3.17: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:4.1: Soon afterwards, after robing up in the morning, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and went to a certain family with Venerable Ānanda as his attendant.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:4.2: He sat down on the prepared seat, and the people there gave staple food.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:4.3: Being afraid of wrongdoing, Ānanda did not accept it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:4.5: “I can’t, Venerable Sir, I’m expecting another meal.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:4.6: “Well then, Ānanda, transfer that meal to someone else and then receive this.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:4.7: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:4.8: “Monks, I allow you to eat a meal before another if you transfer the other meal to someone else.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:4.9: And, monks, this is how it should be transferred: ‘I give my expected meal to so-and-so.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.1.2: if he has been invited to eat any of the five staple foods, and he then eats any of the five staple foods elsewhere—this is called “eats a meal before another”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.1.4: unless it is an appropriate occasion.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.1.6: if he is not able to eat as much as he needs in one sitting, he may eat a meal before another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.1.8: if he has not participated in the robe-making procedure, he may eat a meal before another during the last month of the rainy season. If he has participated in the robe-making procedure, he may eat a meal before another during the five month period.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.1.9: It is a time of making robes:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.1.10: when he is making robes, he may eat a meal before another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.1.11: If he receives food with the intention of eating it, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.1.12: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.2.1: If it is a meal before another, and he perceives it as such, and he eats it, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.2.2: If it is a meal before another, but he is unsure of it, and he eats it, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.2.3: If it is a meal before another, but he does not perceive it as such, and he eats it, except on an appropriate occasion, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.2.4: If it is not a meal before another, but he perceives it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.2.5: If it is not a meal before another, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.2.6: If it is not a meal before another, and he does not perceive it as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.2: if it is an appropriate occasion;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.3: if he transfers his other meal to someone else and then eats;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.4: if he eats the food from two or three invitational meals together;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.5: if he eats the meals in the same order that the invitations were received;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.6: if he is invited by a whole village and he eats anywhere in that village;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.7: if he is invited by a whole association and he eats anywhere within that association;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.8: if, when being invited, he says, “I’ll get almsfood;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.9: if it is a regular meal invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.10: if it is a meal for which lots are drawn;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.11: if it is a half-monthly meal;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.12: if it is on the observance day;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.13: if it is on the day after the observance day;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.14: if it is anything apart from the five staple foods;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.16: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc33:5.3.17: The third rule, the training rule on eating a meal before another, is finished.
